description: From Middle English skulke, skulken, of North Germanic origin; compare Danish skulke (“shirk”), Swedish skolka (“play truant”).

examples: A skulk of foxes, a cowardice of curs are tonight’s traffic whispering in the yards and lanes.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A group of people seen as being fox-like (e.g. cunning, dishonest, or having nefarious plans).
examples: […]  a skulk of priests flapped out of the Church of San Geronimo, and women kneeling at novena put away their beads  […]

entries.meaning: The act of moving in a stealthy or furtive way.
examples: A part of their company, who had been sent out on a skulk, had not returned, and great anxiety was felt lest they had fallen into an ambush and been captured.

entries.meaning: A stealthy or furtive gait or way of moving.
examples: His gait was something between a slouch and a skulk.

entries.meaning: The act of avoiding an obligation or responsibility.
examples: [They took] good care  […]  to swing their hammocks as far abaft as possible, for the twofold purpose of having a skulk in their watch below at night, and to keep clear of the sprays, which usually pour down the gratings  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete, chiefly nautical, military) One who avoids an obligation or responsibility.

verbs.description: skulk (third-person singular simple present skulks, present participle skulking, simple past and past participle skulked)

entries.meaning: To stay where one cannot be seen, conceal oneself (often in a cowardly way or with the intent of doing harm).
To move in a stealthy or furtive way; to come or go while trying to avoid detection.
To avoid an obligation or responsibility.
